div1.p: Many thanks for the box of letters; I will let you know as soon as they arrive so that you will not worry about them. I wish you would send them express collect; getting them boxed and sent is trouble enough, and you certainly should not have any expense in the shipping. That is a small thing for me to do when you are gicving me so much assistance.

Of course I don't think you are bragging to tell me about speeches. That is important material, and, as you dsay, it's real. The picture isn't full without it. You left ego behind years ago, and I find you much more concerned with truth than anything else. If the nose has a wart you don't want the wart retouched out of the photograph, so to speak. I shall certainly use the Emporia speeches, and the Writers' Conference. That was the time Paul Engle spoke, wasn't it?

I tried to find Mr. Collier when I was in New York, but he is not in the telephone book, and the office of the university was closed. I shall write him again. I have just written to G eorge Bailey and Zander zSulke, whose addresses Mr. Kelly sent me. He has already talked to them and he says they will write. UYesterday I got more Blade film but I can't read it till Monday.

We certainly enjoyed the visits with you. When we get back in June I hope we can talk about the biography. NBy that time I should have assembled more material assembled on the criticisms in the Minneapolis Journal and the Kansas City Post, and I'd like to have your recommendations for expanding certain parts. It's a wonderful story to write.
Remember to tell me about any speeches you make from now on, and when you get to the Poetics I do want to know what you think of the theories.
Our best wishes to all of you for a happy new year. All your years are good; I hope this one will be special.

postscript.p: The letters just came, and I dropped everything and read most of them. The only thing that stpopped me is that I wanted to get this letter ready before Bower calls to be picked up.

If you read these letters over before you sent them you can imagine how delighted I am. They are wonderful! Mrs. Neihardt's letter about children is beautiful, and yours on prayer is one of the best. There must be a collection of letters someday--everyone should read these things. They tell a good deal about speeches too. Thank you again for sending them. But do let me pay the charges; if you'll tell me the amount I can showend you a check or stamps.
